prior_works.title: The Strength of Weak Learnability
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Defines the core weak-to-strong boosting paradigm that this paper analyzes under parallel constraints, supplying the baseline notion of boosting rounds and weak learners whose adaptivity the new results quantify.

prior_works.title: A Decision-Theoretic Generalization of On-Line Learning and an Application to Boosting
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the prototypical adaptive reweighting procedure whose inherent sequential dependence motivates the paper’s p-versus-t tradeoff analysis and the design of a parallel counterpart.

prior_works.title: Smooth Boosting and Learning with Malicious Noise
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces smooth boosting techniques that achieve near sample-optimality, a regime explicitly targeted by the new paper when settling the parallel complexity of nearly sample-optimal boosters.

prior_works.title: Efficient Noise-Tolerant Learning from Statistical Queries
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the query-based lens under which many boosting procedures can be expressed, enabling the paper’s lower-bound methodology on adaptive rounds versus parallel work for weak-to-strong learning.

prior_works.title: Statistical Algorithms and a Lower Bound for Detecting Planted Cliques
prior_works.authors: Vitaly Feldman, Elena Grigorescu, Lev Reyzin, Santosh Vempala, Ying Xiao
prior_works.role: General lower-bound framework for SQ/statistical algorithms
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the modern lower-bound machinery used to argue about the limits of parallel (non-adaptive) queries, which the paper adapts to derive tighter lower bounds along the entire p–t spectrum for boosting.

prior_works.title: The Adaptive Complexity of Maximizing a Submodular Function
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Develops the paradigm of proving tradeoffs between the number of adaptive rounds and per-round work, a methodological template the paper leverages to sharpen and match lower bounds for parallel boosting.

prior_works.title: The Multiplicative Weights Update Method: A Meta-Algorithm and Applications
prior_works.authors: Sanjeev Arora, Elad Hazan, Satyen Kale
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Formalizes the MWU viewpoint of boosting, informing the paper’s design of a parallel boosting algorithm whose updates can be structured to meet the lower-bound-matching p–t tradeoffs.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—tight lower bounds and matching algorithms for the parallel complexity of boosting across the full tradeoff between rounds (p) and per-round work (t) for nearly sample-optimal boosters—rests on two intertwined lines of prior work. First are the foundational boosting results: Schapire’s weak-to-strong transformation and Freund–Schapire’s AdaBoost establish the adaptive, distribution-reweighting process and define the objects (weak learners, boosting rounds) whose sequential nature challenges parallelization. Servedio’s SmoothBoost demonstrates that one can achieve near sample-optimality via carefully controlled (smooth) distributions, directly motivating the regime this paper settles.
Second is the methodological backbone for proving and achieving parallel tradeoffs. Kearns’s Statistical Query framework and Feldman et al.’s statistical algorithms lower-bound machinery provide a way to reason about what non-adaptive or limited-adaptivity procedures can and cannot learn, enabling round–work lower bounds for weak-to-strong transformations. Complementing this, the adaptivity literature in optimization—exemplified by Balkanski and Singer’s rounds-vs-queries tradeoffs—supplies techniques to map the number of adaptive rounds to achievable performance under parallel query budgets. Finally, the multiplicative-weights perspective of boosting (Arora–Hazan–Kale) informs the constructive side: it yields structured updates amenable to batched, parallel execution. Together, these works equip the paper to (i) tighten lower bounds for weak-to-strong learners across the entire p–t spectrum and (ii) design a nearly sample-optimal, parallel boosting algorithm that matches these limits up to logarithmic factors, thereby resolving the parallel complexity landscape for boosting.
